entry.title: Limitation in SAP RFID Handling unit number series Length
entry.content:
We have integration between a third party RFID solution with SAP. The challenge is with the Handling unit number series length:

 

  • The Third Party RFID solution supports 28 character length
  • SAP HU number series is restricted to a maximum of character length.

 

This limitation is causing integration issues. we need feasible solution or workaround where the HU numbers from the third-party RFID can be aligned with SAP. Request your urgent guidance as this is very critical for our go live.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: How the capacity planning works in warehouse management (public cloud)?
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

Could you please explain how capacity planning functions in warehouse management within SAP Public Cloud?

The client’s requirement involves handling two types of storage bins:

  • Storage bin with a capacity of 1.0 TO

  • Storage bin with a capacity of 1.5 TO

There is a material called SS wire roll, which is procured from different suppliers and varies in weight. Using batch-specific units of measure during synchronous goods receipt, the process is as follows:

  • Material with a weight less than or equal to 1.0 TO should be placed in a 1.0 TO bin.

  • Material with a weight greater than 1.0 TO but less than or equal to 1.5 TO should be stored in a 1.5 TO bin

Additionally, if all 1.0 TO bins are full, materials weighing less than or equal to 1.0 TO may need to be placed in a 1.5 TO bin, with up to 4 quantities per bin depending on their size.

 

How the process can be mapped in sap public cloud warehouse management? please advise me on priority.

entry.title: Issue with Batch-Specific UOM Quantity Display in Warehouse Monitor vs MMBE in SAP Public Cloud.
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

While receiving material with batch-specific UOM through synchronous goods receipt in Warehouse Management in SAP Public Cloud, I observed an issue.

The base UOM for the material is TO, and the alternative UOM is EA. I am receiving the material in EA with a batch-specific UOM ratio, where each EA is considered as a handling unit. However, when I check the received quantity in the Warehouse Monitor app, the EA is displayed according to the batch-specific UOM ratio instead of reflecting the actual received quantity in EA.

On the other hand, when I check in MMBE, the receiving quantity is displayed correctly.

Could you please advise on the reason for this discrepancy and the possible resolution?

entry.title: SAP Public cloud and Warehouse bin migration object
entry.content:
Hi,

Is creation of warehouse bins supported in SAP Public Cloud with migration objects or is it supposed to update existing bin data_

Warehouse storage bin | SAP Help Portal

In the documentation it says is should be possible to create bins, but we are getting error You cannot create new object in wh...

In migration object template, there is information Note that the storage bin must already exist. 

When the bin already exists in system, and then try to update them,  we are getting error Storage bin already exists.., 

So which function the warehouse bin migration object supports_

entry.title: enable barcode for Serial ID on RF screen
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

We have a requirement to enable Barcode for Serial ID field in Bin-to-Bin scenario. Upon scanning the barcode string, Serial ID need be decoded so that it gets added as new line item to the scanned List.

This way business will get to know how many serial Ids are scanned.

 FM - /SCWM/RF_XSERNR_PAI gets triggered when you enter Serial Id manually or when 2D barcode string is entered in Input field.

It is working when we enter Serial ID manually hit enter.  Serial ID gets add to the scanned list as below.

In the standard RF screen, Serial ID field is just declared of type Input/Output. We have created custom screen and enabled property Barcode = 'TRUE' and checked it as scrollable. default length made it as 255, output as 18.

As we declared output length as 18 and we are passing input as 2D barcode string, ABAP dump is raised with message ‘Output field too short for converted value’ because of the SERIAL ID conversion exit routine.

Dump says System is expecting plain Serial ID as an input. We validated BADI - /SCWM/EX_BARC_DECODE but it is not triggering in our case.

FYI - Conversion routine is triggered before PAI FM is triggered.

Expectation – We are looking for BADI or Enhancement before Routine where we can write custom logic to decode the barcode string and pass Serial Id as input (like we are currently entering manually).

I just wanted to check if anyone has worked on similar kind of requirement.

RF menu Path - 050205, Logical transaction -AHPRTO, step - XSERNR

 

Thank you.

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: SAP EWM process codes and its language
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

we are configured/using Process codes(as Z*) to stop PGI, if they are having any defect in DO items. We are created new program and assigned to EWM monitor as new node.. Now the program working fine as per expected functionality... Here the problem is with data stored in table level and its Language dependency..

Ex: My client login with Japanese language and using this codes (with description Japanese) and store it in DB .. when he again  login with EN .. he want to see the same descriptions in EN.... Please do the needful.

Best Regards,

Gowrisankar

entry.title: Intermediate storage bin EWM
entry.content:
Hi!

It is possible to create intermediate bins linked to a resource responsible for the storage bin and the respective addresses of the materials allocated to them. The position would be a temporary systemic allocation that precedes the final storage bins in the warehouse, aiming to fully complete the storage task.

entry.title: LE-WM is Ending: Understanding Stock Room Management vs EWM — What’s Next for Your Warehouse in SAP
entry.content:
Introduction

Warehouse Management (WM), part of SAP’s classic LE-WM (Logistics Execution – Warehouse Management) functionality, has been widely used in SAP ECC and S/4HANA for decades. However, SAP has announced that LE-WM is not the target architecture anymore. After 31 December 2025, LE-WM will no longer be usable under the compatibility scope in S/4HANA.

SAP provides two main alternatives:

  • Stock Room Management (SRM) – for customers with simpler warehouse processes.

  • Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) – SAP’s strategic, feature-rich solution for advanced needs.

    This blog consolidates SAP Notes and official guidance to help you evaluate your migration options.

LE-WM in S/4HANA: Compatibility Mode

  • SAP Note 2270211: “Warehouse Management (LE-WM) is not the target architecture anymore within SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition. The available alternatives are Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM) and, since S/4HANA 1909, Stock Room Management.”

  • SAP Note 2577428: LE-WM is available in S/4HANA only in a compatibility mode until 31.12.2025, after which it cannot be used.

  • No technical migration is needed if you switch from LE-WM to Stock Room Management — but you must operate within its defined scope.

Key takeaway: LE-WM is frozen. For long-term sustainability, customers must plan for SRM or EWM.

Stock Room Management (SRM): The Lean Alternative

Introduced in S/4HANA 1909, Stock Room Management allows existing LE-WM customers to continue using basic warehouse processes beyond 2025.

According to SAP Note 2881166 (FAQ: Stock Room Management):

  • Reuses major parts of LE-WM but limited to elementary core processes.

  • Designed for companies that do not require advanced warehouse processes.

  • Covers functions like: storage bin management, goods receipt/issue, internal warehouse movements, physical inventory.

  • Does not include: TRM, VAS, Yard Management, Cross-Docking, Wave Management, or Decentral WM.

  • Included in the SAP S/4HANA Enterprise Management license (no extra cost).

Important: SAP has no plans to enhance Stock Room Management. Innovations and new features will only come in EWM.

Clarification 

“Stock Room Management is not officially limited to 2025, but innovations are frozen. For on-premise customers, SRM is the supported option beyond 2025, while for RISE customers, SAP has extended certain use rights until 2030 (see Note 2269324).

Compliance Check: Are You Eligible for SRM?

SAP provides a tool to check whether your current WM setup fits into SRM’s restricted scope.

From SAP Note 2882809 (Scope Compliance Check):

  • Run the program STOCKROOM_COMPLIANCE_CHECK in your S/4HANA system.

  • The report verifies whether your processes align with SRM scope.

  • If compliant, you can continue beyond 2025 with minimal changes.

Extended Warehouse Management (EWM): The Strategic Path

While SRM is a “maintenance bridge,” SAP’s strategic warehouse solution is EWM.

SAP Notes 2270211 and 2577428 emphasize:

  • New warehouses should be implemented in EWM.

  • EWM provides advanced functionality: automation, integration with material flow systems, cross-docking, yard management, wave planning, and more.

  • EWM is actively developed with continuous innovations and Fiori-based apps.

If your warehouse operations are complex, highly automated, or expected to scale, EWM is the safer long-term choice.

Comparison: SRM vs. EWM

Feature Stock Room Management (SRM) Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

AvailabilitySince S/4HANA 1909Embedded & Decentral (S/4HANA, SCM)
ScopeCore/basic WM processesFull-featured, advanced warehouse processes
LicenseIncluded in S/4HANA EMRequires additional license (except Basic EWM)
InnovationsNone (frozen)Continuous investment and enhancements
Best suited forSimple warehousesComplex/automated warehouses

Migration Roadmap: What Customers Should Do Now

  1. Assess Current Usage

    • Identify which LE-WM functionalities you are using.

    • Run the Scope Compliance Check (Note 2882809).

  2. Decide Between SRM and EWM

    • If your needs are basic → SRM may be sufficient.

    • If your needs are advanced or future-oriented → move to EWM.

  3. Plan the Migration

    • For SRM → minimal changes, but ensure compliance.

    • For EWM → plan a proper migration project with process redesign, data migration, and training.

  4. Act Early

    • Migration projects take time and resources. Start before 2025.

      Migration from WM to EWM: A High-Level View

      If your warehouse operations exceed what Stock Room Management can support, moving from LE-WM to Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) becomes the logical next step. Below is a concise overview + key resources.

       

      Stock Migration

      You can use this function to migrate stock data from LE-WM into SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM).

      Prerequisites

      • You have defined all the storage bins for which you want to transfer the stocks from LE-WM to EWM.

      • There are no open documents (for example, inbound delivery, outbound delivery, and so on).

      • You have created the handling unit types in EWM that also exist in ERP.

      • You have transferred the packaging materials that exist in ERP to EWM.

      • You have mapped the storage unit types to packaging materials (see Map Storage Unit Type to Packaging Material).

      • You have run the storage bin migration function and created all the necessary bins in EWM. For more information, see Storage Bin Migration.

      • You have run the warehouse product migration function for all products that exist in the stock being migrated. For more information, see Warehouse Product Migration.

      Features

      Direction

      • Download from LE-WM: The data is imported from LE-WM and saved in a file, taking into consideration the parameters specified in the following sections.

      • Upload to EWM: The data is available in a file and ready to be uploaded to EWM.

      Data Source

      ERP Business System specifies the LE-WM system from which the data is to be imported.

      Data Selection

      • ERP Plant (mandatory)

      • ERP Storage Location (optional)

      • ERP Warehouse Number (mandatory)

      • ERP Storage Type (optional)

      • ERP Storage Bin (optional)

      You can use the optional parameters, for example, to limit the amount of data or to carry out the migration in separate iterations.

      Conversion Rules

      EWM Warehouse Number specifies the EWM warehouse number to which the data should be uploaded. This entry is mandatory.

      File Destination

      • Local File: indicates if the file is in the local directory

      • Logical File: indicates if the file is in the application server

      • File Name: entry for the file name and its directory

      • File Type: the file type used by the report (only CSV files are supported)

      Display Control

      • Display Downloaded Data: When you select this checkbox, the data downloaded from LE-WM is displayed after import as an ALV.

      • Include Entries with Error: When you select this checkbox, data that contains errors (such as stocks that still have open documents) are included in the migration.

      Activities

      The function should be executed in two steps:

      1. Export the data from LE-WM and save it in a file.

      2. Use the report Initial Stock Data Transfer to upload the data to EWM, by selecting the Upload radio button. For more information, see Initial Stock Data Transfer.

      •  

      Key SAP Resources / Documentation

      For readers wanting to dig into the detailed technical and procedural guidance, here are useful SAP help links:

      • SAP Help for EWM version 9.0: general documentation and architecture.

      • Specific Help topics about migrating master data, warehouse product data, storage bin migration, and stock migration.

      • SAP Help sections that describe how to configure EWM, integrate it, and transition from LE-WM.

      You can find these via:

      • SAP EWM 9.0 help portal

      • Other EWM 9.0 topics (e.g. storage bin content, product master, etc.) via the help links you shared.

Conclusion

The message from SAP is consistent across Notes 2270211, 2881166, 2882809, and 2577428:

  • LE-WM ends after 2025.

  • Stock Room Management is only a stop-gap solution for simpler warehouses.

  • SAP EWM is the future of warehouse management in S/4HANA.

Now is the time to evaluate your warehouse landscape, run the compliance check, and plan your roadmap toward SRM or EWM.

Don’t wait — the earlier you act, the smoother your transition will be.
EWM - Basic Functions @ewms LE Warehouse Management SAP Extended Warehouse Management

entry.title: Custom follow up action triggering WPT 1010 instead of Y550 created new one
entry.content:
I have maintained custom follow-up action by copying standard EWM_A, EWM_R. usage codes have been assigned to them and all remaining configuration done from Qm and EWM side.

When I accept the batch in QA32 its triggering standard WPT 1010 instead of Y550 which I created for the custom follow up action.

I have maintained the Y550 as STCH.

Please help me if anything need to change in the FM.

Regards,

Chand

entry.title: Staging of components from an external warehouse to an EWM warehouse
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus, 

In our business case, we have 2 Storage Locations under our plant. Lets call them A and B.

SLOC A is EWM managed. This is where all the production takes place. We have PSAs defined under this EWM warehouse. 

SLOC B is physically situated appx. 10 kms away. This SLOC is declared as a Decentralized Warehouse, run and managed by a 3rd party service provider. 

We have Production Orders, with some components that are stored in SLOC A (EWM warehouse), and some in SLOC B (Dec. warehouse).  The ones that are stored in SLOC B, needs to be moved from this dec. whse. to the PSAs. 

Most of the threads I have come across related to this situation suggests creation of STOs from SLOC B to A. But, is there an SAP standard functionality that can help us create such STOs automatically? Ideally, there should be a way to: 

1. Initiate staging of the components that are stored in the EWM whse to the PSAs, and simultaneously,

2. Automatic creation of the STOs of the components that are stored in the dec. whse. 

Is it somehow possible in SAP std? 

What makes the situation more tricky is that some components can sometimes be stored at both the locations. In that case, if enough stock is available at the EWM warehouse, system should not create the STOs, rather the SAP EWM staging requests. 

Are there any suggestions around this? Thanks for the pointers and leads in advance! 

Regards

Rahul Sharma

entry.title: How to start using SAP Warehouse Insights in the 2025?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I have read a lot of information about SAP Warehouse Insights (WI) on the SAP Community ((Warehouse Insights – The planning and optimization... - SAP Community)). However, I am still not sure what steps are needed to start using WI, especially in a free trial version. By the way, I looked through the note 2863221, it provides steps when we have already connected with the systems (EWM, WI). So, my question here is how to start from scratch.

As far as I know, there are currently no free options to use WI on the some data centers (https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/can-it-still-be-used-warehouse-insights-trial/qaq-p/12510078), and I also do not see WI listed as an available service on the sap discovery center.

In addition, I also tried to find WI on the my employer's BTP sandbox and I found nothing.

Could you please provide more details on whether it is possible to start using SAP WI (free trial or otherwise)? Any guidance on how to get initial access would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance!

Best regards.

entry.title: SAP WM Public cloud storage bin Capacity check planning for putway.
entry.content:
Could you please explain how capacity planning functions in warehouse management within SAP Public Cloud?


The client’s requirement involves handling two types of storage bins:



  • Storage bin with a capacity of 1.0 TO



  • Storage bin with a capacity of 1.5 TO



There is a material called SS wire roll, which is procured from different suppliers and varies in weight. Using batch-specific units of measure during synchronous goods receipt, the process is as follows:



  • Material with a weight less than or equal to 1.0 TO should be placed in a 1.0 TO bin.



  • Material with a weight greater than 1.0 TO but less than or equal to 1.5 TO should be stored in a 1.5 TO bin



Additionally, if all 1.0 TO bins are full, materials weighing less than or equal to 1.0 TO may need to be placed in a 1.5 TO bin, with up to 4 quantities per bin depending on their size.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: SQ01 dynamic date and time filters with timestamps
entry.content:

SAP EWM tables often use timestamps (e.g. /SCWM/ORDIM_C).

Are there any possibilities to use dynamic date and time filters here?

 

Best regards

Jonas

entry.title: Sap MM EWM
entry.content:

I’m from Morocco, I have a Master’s degree and experience in logistics and transportation.

Which one is more suitable for my background and future career opportunities?

Also, what is the usual training duration and cost for each module?

 

Any advice or personal experience would be greatly appreciated. Thanks a lot!
